children.text: Goal 1.1: Understand and use numbers.
Apply properties of rational numbers. (eg. necessary skill for applyingnumbers)

Perform operations using positive and negative numbers, fractions, absolutevalue, decimals, percentages, and scientific notation. (eg. given the cost of aproject, determine what percentage of the budget went for salaries)
Apply properties of exponents. (eg. calculate the power dissipated by a resistorwhen its current and voltage drop are given in exponent form)
Identify perfect squares and their principal roots. (eg. 4, 9, and 16 are perfectsquares and their respective roots are 2, 3, and 4)

Solve problems using number theory concepts. (eg. given initial expenses,money needed for reserve and start-up inventory, calculate the start up costsfor a business by using a Starting Cost Calculator)
Estimate the value of an irrational number expressed as a radical. (eg. calculatethe impedance of an inductive series circuit when given the circuit’s totalresistance and total inductive reactance)
Apply properties of common and natural logarithms. (eg. determine medicationabsorption rate)
Use Fundamental Counting Principles. (eg. calculate number of outfits fromset number of separates)
Use combinations and permutations. (eg. calculate the number of ways to order the digits for a phone number)
Goal 1.2: Understand and perform computations accurately.
Perform fundamental rational expression and number operations that involve a variety of applications. (eg. determine wage and benefits)
Read, write, and solve problems using scientific notation. (eg. determinevoltage of a circuit)
Solve problems using direct and inverse variation. (eg. determine the mechanical advantage of gears)
Perform operations on complex numbers. (eg. find amperage of current, knowing voltage and impedance if the impedance includes inductors or capacitors)
Calculate nth powers and nth roots. (eg. compute interest on investments)
Goal 1.3: Estimate and judge reasonableness of results.
Estimate square roots between consecutive integers. (eg. necessary foundationinformation)
Determine relative and percent of error. (eg. scale drawings must be within (+,-) 1/16th of an inch)
Apply number sense to everyday situations. (eg. approximate grocery totals)

text: Standard 2: Concepts and Principles of Measurement

children.text: Goal 2.1: Understand and use U.S. customary and metric measurements.
Perform metric conversions within the system. (eg. convert medicine dosage from adult to child)
Solve problems by converting between English and metric systems. (eg. trip planning from miles to kilometers and gallons to liters)
Determine length, distance, area, surface area, volume, and weight, with appropriate unit labels. (eg. determine number of flowers needed to fill a flower bed)
Calculate circumference, area, radius, diameter, area of sector, arc length of acircle with appropriate unit labels. (eg. develop a circular watering system)
Goal 2.2: Apply the concepts of rates, ratios, and proportions.
Determine an unknown term in a ratio. (eg. comparing cost of living between cities)
Goal 2.3: Apply dimensional analysis.
Solve U.S. customary weights and measures problems using dimensional analysis. (eg. feet per second to miles per hour)
By use of estimation convey knowledge of volume versus mass. (eg. determine dosage of medicine per weight)
Goal 2.4: Apply appropriate techniques, tools, and formulas to determine measurements.
Determine and use appropriate units. (eg. using an existing recipe, calculate a recipe for a larger group, simplify and label new amounts)

Calculate area, surface area for two dimensional objects and volume for three-dimensional objects. (eg. compute amount of cement needed for a sidewalk; calculate the cost of heating a building based on square footage)

text: Standard 3: Concepts and Language of Algebra and Functions

children.text: Goal 3.1: Use algebraic symbolism as a tool to represent mathematical relationships.
Represent mathematical relationships using variables, expressions, linear equations and inequalities. (eg. using spreadsheet functions, determine sale price of items)
Perform operations on polynomial expressions. (eg. compute regular and overtime gross and net earnings)
Perform operations on radical expressions. (eg. determine flow rate of water through a fire hose)
Perform operations on rational expressions. (eg. determine earnings for a given time frame)
Factor quadratics and other polynomial expressions. (eg. determine flight time of a rocket)
Represent application problems as linear equations. (eg. level of education versus pay; rate of speed versus fuel consumption; caloric intake versus expenditure)
Goal 3.2: Evaluate algebraic expressions.
Perform fundamental operations on polynomial expressions. (eg. calculate the total cost of various items within a meal)
Goal 3.3: Solve algebraic equations and inequalities.
Find solutions to simple quadratic equations. (eg. calculate water content of soil based on its weight)
Solve exponential equations. (eg. determine atmospheric pressure)
Solve logarithmic equations. (eg. determine power of a satellite needed to transmit signals)
Solve absolute value equations. (eg. stopping distance of a car)
Solve systems of inequalities in two variables. (eg. determine needed sales for a company given overhead)
Solve basic one and two step rational equations. (eg. determine amount of medication to administer based on packaging size)
Goal 3.4: Solve simple linear systems of equations.
Solve a system of two linear equations in an application setting. (eg. child care facility – sq. footage to number of children; solving electrical current in a circuit with multiple paths)
Goal 3.5: Understand the concept of functions.

Determine whether a relation is a function given graphs, charts, ordered pairs, mappings, or equations. (eg. graph the distance a ballistic device travels at different angles and determine if the data is a function of the angle)
Differentiate between linear and non-linear functions and graphs. (eg. differentiate between a thrown object and the distance a car travels)
Identify domain and range for given graphs, charts, ordered pairs, mappings, or linear functions. (eg. constraints of any situation such as a budget)
Evaluate functions. (eg. work with the function V=I*R and solve for different I and R)
Goal 3.6: Apply functions to a variety of problems.
Model real-world phenomena with linear functions. (eg. graph fuel consumption versus speed)
Use graphs and tables to represent and solve problems. (eg. stress test of cardiovascular system)
Solve application problems by isolating a specific variable in a formula and then substituting values. (eg. determining interest rate on a loan)

text: Standard 4: Concepts and Principles of Geometry

children.text: Goal 4.1: Apply concepts of size, shape, and spatial relationships.
Identify and apply congruency and similarity of two-dimensional figures. (eg. compare trusses or wall panels)
Identify the scale factor of similar three-dimensional figures and find the ratios of their surface areas and volumes. (eg. compare blueprint to actual model)
Use transformational geometry to rotate, translate, and reflect figures in a coordinate plane. (eg. flip a house plan)
Describe and apply magnitude and direction of vectors. (eg. determine resultant direction due to wind)
Goal 4.2 Apply the geometry of right triangles.
Understand and apply the Pythagorean Theorem for problem solving. (eg. checking accuracy on gate construction)
Identify and apply special right triangle relationships. (eg. isometric drawing in drafting)
Use right triangle trigonometry to solve right triangles. (eg. determine angle ofelevation using sine, cosine and tangent)
Use trigonometric ratios to solve problems. (eg. angle of depression)
Goal 4.3: Apply graphing in two dimensions.
Determine the length and midpoint of a segment in the coordinate plane. (eg.on-center carpentry from a blueprint would include the coordinate plane)
Graph quadratic and absolute value functions. (eg. maximize profit from revenue)
Graph exponential functions. (eg. rate of bacterial growth)
Graph systems of equations and inequalities in two variables. (eg. mixing solutions for weed control)
Goal 4.4: Apply concepts of parallel lines.
Identify the special angle pairs formed by parallel lines and a transversal. (eg.building a gate; designing a quilt)
Apply the properties of special angle pairs formed by parallel lines and a transversal (eg. building a gate; designing a quilt)
Goal 4.5: Apply concepts of polygons.
Classify triangles and quadrilaterals based on their attributes. (eg. labeltriangles and quadrilaterals in a house plan)
Find the sum of the interior and exterior angles of a polygon. (eg. add the interior and exterior angles of a pentagonal swimming pool)
Find the measure of each interior and exterior angle of a regular polygon. (eg. find the degree of angles to create a stop sign)
Determine whether or not a polygon is regular. (eg. design a hexagon table using a circle)
Goal 4.6: Understand basic concepts of a circle.
Identify the parts of a circle including radius, diameter, major/minor arcs, chords, secants and tangents. (eg. necessary foundation information)
Determine the lengths of segments and the measures of angles formed by radii, chords, secants, and tangents. (eg. calculate trim for an arched window)
Goal 4.7: Apply Reasoning Skills.
Goal 4.8: Represent and graph linear relationships.
Construct graphs and write equations and inequalities for linear relationships. (eg. relationship between cost and demand)
Given a linear relationship, interpret the rate of change (slope) and the intercepts. (eg. rate of feed to fill a grain truck)
Write equations of lines given various information including parallel, perpendicular, vertical, and horizontal lines. (eg. alignment of restaurant with layout of city street)
Graph linear equations. (eg. constant increase in water temperature over time; monthly changes in sales)

text: Standard 5: Data Analysis, Probability, and Statistics

children.text: Goal 5.1: Represent data with a variety of formats.
Analyze and interpret tables, charts and graphs. (eg. interpret a body mass index (BMI) chart)
Goal 5.2: Collect, organize, and display data.
Graph scatter plots and informal trend lines. (eg. growth of state economy)
Identify positive and negative correlations. (eg. vehicle depreciation)
Collect, organize, and display data in tables, charts and graphs. (eg. chart change in stock values over 4 weeks)
Goal 5.3: Apply simple statistical measurements.

Make predictions and draw conclusions based on statistical measures. (eg. predict the number of new jobs based on growth in population; predict the number of sunny days in a given area for a given time frame)
Goal 5.4: Understand basic concepts of probability.
Goal 5.5: Make predictions or decisions based on data.
Make predictions based on randomness, chance, equally likely events, and probability. (eg. predict the likelihood of having an accident using past accident data)
Use data to predict the chance of an event. (eg. calculate the odds of a hit based on the batting average)
